title: Girls Shot Put Distances: Describe the Distribution
question_text:
The histogram below shows results for the $23$ girls who competed in the shot put event at a state track and field meet.
Created for Albert.io. Copyright 2016. All rights reserved.

Which of the following best describes the distribution?

choices.text:
The distribution is unimodal with a range of
6
meters.

The distribution is skewed left with a median at
10.5
meters and no obvious outliers.

The distribution is skewed left with a mean of
12.5
meters and at least one high outlier.

The distribution is skewed right with a median between
11
and
12
meters.

The distribution is skewed right with a range of
6
meters.

solution:
One easy way to determine the shape of a distribution from a histogram is to outline the histogram as shown below.

Created for Albert.io. Copyright 2016. All rights reserved.



Since the outline is mound shaped on the left and more spread out on the right, we can conclude that the distribution is skewed right.

Choices 'B' and 'C' can be eliminated because the distribution is not skewed left.

The histogram has only one peak, or one most common interval of values. Therefore, as well as being skewed right, we can also conclude that the distribution is unimodal! Most of the distances were
11
but less than
12
meters.

To determine which choice provides the best description of the distribution, we need to consider the range and the median.

The left-most bar in the histogram indicates that the lowest distance was at least
9
but less than
10
meters. The right-most bar in the histogram indicates that the highest distance was at least
14
but less than
15
meters. If we assume that the minimum distance was
9
and the maximum distance was something very close to
15
, like
14.99
for example, then we might say that the range was approximately
6
.

However, we do not know even this much to be true! We only know that the minimum distance was at least
9
but less than
10
meters. Perhaps the minimum distance was
9.9
meters. Likewise, we only know that the maximum distance was at least
14
but less than
15
meters. It is possible that the maximum distance was only
14.1
meters. Under this scenario, the range would be
14.1
âˆ’
9.9
=
4.2
meters which is not close to a range of
6
!

It seems then, that we should also eliminate Choices 'A' and 'E' since we cannot be certain that the range is
6
meters.

This leaves Choice 'D'.

Choice 'D' correctly identifies the distribution as being skewed right and also says that the median is between
11
and
12
meters. While we cannot determine the exact value of the median, we can verify that the median is between
11
and
12
meters.

The median is the middle number (or average of two middle numbers) when the observations are arranged in order from lowest to highest. Since there were
23
observations, the
12
th
highest value would be the median. Find the median by matching up the height of each bar with the frequency shown on the vertical axis. Keep track of cumulative frequencies until you reach the
12
th
highest value.

This means that the
12
th
highest value is somewhere between
11
and
12
meters.

Choice 'D' accurately describes the distribution.
